'Demon' leers over man's shoulder
 
 Even if religion is wrong and there is no dog in that photo, you can't deny that it's "superstition" that allowed this guy to break a drug habit.

post_info.post_title: Who says good doesn't come out of religion?

Symbiote

At the risk of psychologising someone who I have no knowledge of apart from what is posted in this thread, it looks like a fairly typical case of Fundamental attribution error - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia 
 
 There is a well documented tendency for people to attribute things they feel bad about to external forces. In this case that would be demonic influence, but could equally well be bad parenting, a breakup with a girlfriend, etc.
 
 A parallel example, the well known Alcoholics Anonymous program is attributed by many former or recovering alcoholics with turning their life around; there would apparently be no denying they were instrumental. But when we try to test the effectiveness of the program, people who go through the process are no more successful in kicking the habit than those who don't follow any method at all. Yet Alcoholics Anonymous continues to be extremely popular, despite its general uselessness, because it is very easy to convince people that their addiction is not something they have influence over.
 
 It seems equally plausible to me that he would have given up his habits anyway and the pretty unconvincing image of a demon, that really looks 100% like an average dog, was merely a convenient conscious or unconscious excuse that helped to explain away his socially unacceptable behaviour.
 
 For all I know maybe in this individual instance it did turn him around, but I'm not convinced without some kind of controlled study (which would be almost impossible to conduct and would probably violate about 10 ethical rules of human experimentation) that this kind of photo would positively influence the average person.
 
 And tell you what, for someone to be a drug addict and attending an anniversary reception of all things, looking respectable in a tuxedo, he's already apparently in a lifestyle much easier to give up on drugs in than 99% of addicts.
Ethmi
You make it sound as if this is a bad thing. Even if it is an error, had he not noticed the dog-like thing or had not believed in it, he'd probably still be on drugs.
Symbiote

Well that's what I'm saying, there's no evidence apart from his personal anecdote that a dog or dog puppet like the one below did turn his life around.
 
 As with AA, it's easy to come to believe it did turn your life around, because it holds the promise that it wasn't your fault to begin with, but there's no evidence it actually does. There's no evidence it doesn't either, but you could say that about a lot of things.
 
 http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/1/16/ComePoopWithMe.jpg
Ethmi

Good luck convincing anyone that he would've made that decision had he not seen the photo. It's apparently had so little effect that he carries it wherever he goes.
 
 This may not make sense, but I don't understand why people are so obsessed with evidence. Do you have anything other than belief to prove that your entire life is not a hallucination? It could be that you are a spark of energy, the only thing in existence, a being that is deceived by perception. Or in a few minutes you could wake up in a cave and tell your family about a dream you had where you were a hideous, two-legged creature sitting in a room with four perfectly flat walls and using a strange device to communicate with a stranger hundreds of miles from you.
 
 I suppose I'm wasting time here. You will not be convinced that the photo changed this guy's life because it's something you refuse to believe. Evidence is the shell you use to hide from the truth.
Symbiote

Good luck convincing anyone that he would've made that decision had he not seen the photo. It's apparently had so little effect that he carries it wherever he goes.

 
 You mean like an AA membership card? A sort of symbolic reminder of your own fundamental goodness that was once undermined by forces beyond your control?
 
 
Do you have anything other than belief to prove that your entire life is not a hallucination? 

 
 No, but I don't have any evidence for that to be the case either.
 
 
You will not be convinced that the photo changed this guy's life because it's something you refuse to believe. Evidence is the shell you use to hide from the truth.

 
 Maybe it did, maybe it didn't. I don't have a problem with the possibility it did, any more than I have a problem with the possibility of being an egocentric spark. I do have the problem with the statement "you can't deny that it's "superstition" that allowed this guy to break a drug habit. ", it's logically equivalent to "you cannot deny that you are the sole spark in existence". Following this logic, I would have to simultaneously hold every conceivable position, all of them contradictory to most the other ones. Not really a healthy way to live, see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_dissonance
Ethmi

You mean like an AA membership card?

 
 
"I look at it and I carry it wherever I go," he told the television station.

 
 That's exactly what the article says. If his own words won't convince you then I guess nothing will.
 
 
No, but I don't have any evidence for that to be the case either.

 
 I'm not saying that is the case. In fact, I believe that you exist as a flesh and blood human being and that you are currently sitting at a computer and writing responses to me. But your argument is that I don't have sufficient evidence to prove that the photo changed his life because you refuse to accept the evidence in the article. Yet you've made it clear that your thoughts on the matter are not ambiguous. Ambiguous thoughts are the only way you can make it reasonable for you to deny evidence presented. You could not defend an argument that says "that's wrong", so you change it to "maybe that's wrong" to defend your views. 
 
 
Maybe it did, maybe it didn't.  I don't have a problem with the possibility it did, any more than I have a problem with the possibility of being a spark. I do have the problem with the statement "you can't deny that it's "superstition" that allowed this guy to break a drug habit. "

 
 Nice try. I don't think your thoughts on this article are ambiguous. I think you have some very clear thoughts on the matter. You proved it to me.
 
 
For all I know maybe in this individual instance it did turn him around, but I'm not convinced without some kind of controlled study (which would be almost impossible to conduct and would probably violate about 10 ethical rules of human experimentation) that this kind of photo would positively influence the average person.

 
 Right there you said it. You're not convinced because you don't believe that the photo changed this guy's life, and you are trying to put into question the possibility of it being a life-changer rather than just coming out and saying that it isn't. Just calling this guy a liar would be a rather hard position to defend, I imagine. In this case, "maybe that's wrong" is easier to defend than "that's wrong".
pappillion001

'Demon' leers over man's shoulder
 
 Even if religion is wrong and there is no dog in that photo, you can't deny that it's "superstition" that allowed this guy to break a drug habit.

 
 Ok I can agree that religion is a superstition, which is defined as 
 
 1. a belief or notion, not based on reason or knowledge, in or of the ominous significance of a particular thing, circumstance, occurrence, proceeding, or the like.
 2. a system or collection of such beliefs.
 3. a custom or act based on such a belief.
 4. irrational fear of what is unknown or mysterious, esp. in connection with religion.
 5. any blindly accepted belief or notion.
 
 It seems your intent is to find some indisputable justification for religion. Your reasoning though encompasses so much that it becomes meaningless for that purpose. 
 
 I won't argue objects or ideas can have value but limited to the amount a person or group gives it and even that is perspective. He attributes it to religion, using the same evidence I say it's ugly dogs. People believe a rabbit's foot will bring them luck, hopefully more than it brought the rabbit. My ex wife was raised believing it was bad luck to pass salt hand to hand, big family, one salt shaker, very annoying. 
 
 The intent of objective evidence is to seperate what is fact from fiction. Otherwise I may come to the conclusion that priestly pedophiles are a message from God saying he approves or conversely that he doesn't want kids in religion. Maybe snake oil really does everything it claims. 
 
 Out of curiosity is there a particular religion you had in mind?
Penfold

His picture, or an AA card, is a talisman, carried to ward off the evil addiction. It works so long as he believes it does, but there is no direct cause or effect. If anything it denies his personal achievement by attributing the result of his own effort to an outside unrelated cause.

Penfold

Can you prove that? Can you prove that he'd be off drugs had he not seen the photo?

 
 I merely supply a rational explanation for what you claim without evidence to be a causal relationship. The onus of proof is yours.
Ethmi

I merely supply a rational explanation for what you claim without evidence to be a causal relationship. The onus of proof is yours.

 
 No, the evidence I provided was in the OP. You're the one making the assertion here, it's your job to prove that the photo didn't change this guy's life; to back up your "rational explanation".
 
 When somebody provides evidence it's your job to provide evidence to refute it, not to say "I don't like that, provide something else".
iangb

Even if religion is wrong and there is no dog in that photo, you can't deny that it's "superstition" that allowed this guy to break a drug habit.
Even a broken clock is right twice a day, etc.
 
 Actually, I'm of the opinion that religion can have tremendously positive effects sometimes - and there are far better examples than these. That doesn't reveal anything about the truth value of the religion/superstition, however, nor does it say anything about the overall cost/benefit of people adopting the beliefs. That argument is a looooooooooooong one.
pappillion001

Is there some point to all this? Could you simplify?
 
 
 
 Nope. :)

 
 You wanted to provide an example of religion having a positive impact thereby affirming it posseses beneficial value. 
 
 I don't disagree that an example exists, but the one you provided doesn't. He attributes his sobriety to his belief that he had been given a warning that he was walking with Satan. Although it took this religious man eight years and his wife's observation to understand the message, that interpretation was enough to quit. 
 
 The only thing religious about the picture is his interpretation of what he saw. Even as an addict he was praying for help from God, which appearantly didn't happen until the picture. Given the same circumstances he could have attributed his abstanance to the power of an ugly dog or after years of abuse he is older, his health isn't good and his resolve and support were stronger than before.
 
 If the idea of Devine intervention works for him great, but your a long way from being able to say that is what caused this to occur.
